prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my sister’s boyfriend he’s not “family”?
My sister has been dating this guy for less than three months.  My personal feelings are that he’s an idiot.  I mean he’s young (either late teens or early twenties, idk) so it’s understandable.  I was an idiot back then too.  My problem with him is that he’s made some dangerous choices with my sister involved.  He wrecked his truck with her in it driving drunk.  He also took my sister around this ex felon that everyone in town knows is scary dude just so he could buy some “pot” if it was really pot.  The guy sells a lot more than pot.  He’s definitely not someone I want knowing or getting close with my sister.  

Despite that, it’s her choice who she dates so I’ve kept my opinions to myself until now.  I think he mistook politeness for friendship or something.  He’s shown up at my apartment to hang out.  When I visit my mom’s and he’s there he will basically attache himself to my hip.  Most annoying of all he started calling me brother and fam.  I know those aren’t always specifically referring to actual family, but it’s just what it’s felt like.  

It really got under my skin quickly.  The last time he did it I told him, “You’re not my family.  You’re the guy my sister is dating for now.”   He just said “alright” and I walked away. 

He’s just trying to be friendly and get close with his girlfriend’s family, I understand that.  It felt like it was time for a reality check on our relationship though.  I probably pissed my sister off in the process, I haven’t heard from her since it happened.  



"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

First, the sister has been dating the guy for less than three months. The author has concerns about the boyfriend's behavior—like driving drunk with the sister in the car and hanging out with a known ex-felon. Telling someone they aren't family in a direct manner, especially after they've been making efforts to bond with the family, could come off as hostile or dismissive. The author might have wanted to set boundaries without being confrontational. 

The key points here are the intention behind the author's action and the context of the relationship. The author's main concern is valid because the boyfriend's behaviors are risky. But the way they addressed it could have been more tactful. Instead of a blunt statement, maybe a private conversation with the sister first or a more diplomatic approach with the boyfriend. 

The boyfriend's actions of trying to integrate into the family might be well-meaning, but the author has the right to feel uncomfortable. However, the method of confrontation might have been too harsh, leading to the sister cutting off communication. The author's responsibility is to their sister's well-being, but they should also consider how their actions affect the family dynamics and the sister's autonomy in her relationship.

In terms of right and wrong, the author's intentions are protective, but the execution might be flawed. The boyfriend's actions are concerning, but the author's response could have been more constructive. So, while the author isn't entirely in the wrong because they are addressing valid safety concerns, their approach might have been inappropriate. Therefore, the answer might be a nuanced "Yes" because the method could have been better handled, even if the intent was good.
